wrap-examples

For ease of testing all files use absolute paths for wrappers. This is of course configurable. This file is automatically generated from unit tests. You can view source code for tests here

Single method

C++ code

class Q {
  public:
    int a;
    void hhh() { a += 2; };
    int qq() { return 1; };
};

Code using wrapper

var q: Q
q.hhh()
echo q.qq()

Execution result

1

Nim wrappers generated for all dependent files

#============================ Type definition ============================#
type
  Q* {.importcpp: "Q", header: "/tmp/wrapgen-test.cpp".} = object
    a*: int

#================================ Methods ================================#
proc hhh*(self: var Q): void {.importcpp: "#.hhh(@)", header: "/tmp/wrapgen-test.cpp".}
proc qq*(self: var Q): int {.importcpp: "#.qq(@)", header: "/tmp/wrapgen-test.cpp".}

Namespace & includes

C++ code

#include <iostream>

namespace Q {
  class Z {
    public:
      void hello() const { std::cout << "Hello from C++ code"; };
  };
}

Code using wrapper

let z = Z()
z.hello()

Execution result

Hello from C++ code

Nim wrappers generated for all dependent files

#============================ Type definition ============================#
type
  Z* {.importcpp: "Q::Z", header: "/tmp/wrapgen-test.cpp".} = object

#================================ Methods ================================#
proc hello*(self: Z): void {.importcpp: "#.hello(@)", header: "/tmp/wrapgen-test.cpp".}

Wrapping operators

C++ code

#include <iostream>

class Z {
  public:
    int a;
    void operator+=(const Z& rhs) { a += rhs.a; }
};

Code using wrapper

var z = Z(a: cint 12)
z += Z(a: cint 22)
echo z.a

Execution result

34

Nim wrappers generated for all dependent files

#============================ Type definition ============================#
type
  Z* {.importcpp: "Z", header: "/tmp/wrapgen-test.cpp".} = object
    a*: int

#================================ Methods ================================#
proc `+=`*(self: var Z; rhs: Z): void {.importcpp: "# += #",
                                 header: "/tmp/wrapgen-test.cpp".}

Wrapping template classes

C++ code

#include <iostream>
#include <typeinfo>

template <typename T>
class Z {
  public:
    void getParam() const {
      std::cout << "Template parameter name [" <<
        typeid(T).name() << "] \n";
    }
};

Code using wrapper

let z = Z[tuple[a: int, b: float]]()
z.getParam()

Execution result

Template parameter name [34tyTuple__89aXlEye1i9aeqivFuq9bHRDQ]

Nim wrappers generated for all dependent files

#============================ Type definition ============================#
type
  Z*[T] {.importcpp: "Z", header: "/tmp/wrapgen-test.cpp".} = object

#================================ Methods ================================#
proc getParam*[T](self: Z[T]): void {.importcpp: "#.getParam(@)",
                                  header: "/tmp/wrapgen-test.cpp".}

Single external dependency

C++ code

#include "dependency.hpp"
// Main file that we are interseted in wrapping
// Public API uses type `D` that was imported from another
// header. In order to compile wraper we must know how this
// type is defined (where it is imported from etc.) or treat
// it as opaque handle - e.g provide no implementation except
// for `type D {.importcpp: "someheader".} = object`
class Q { public: D dep; };

Nim wrappers generated for all dependent files

dependency.hpp

class D { public: int d; };

Wrapper for dependency /tmp/inferapi-test/dependency.hpp

#============================ Type definition ============================#
type
  D* {.importcpp: "D", header: "/tmp/inferapi-test/dependency.hpp".} = object
    d*: int

#================================ Methods ================================#

Code using wrapper

var q: Q
echo typeof q.dep

Execution result

D
